bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, March 17, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg thanks Agramonte's daughter for her comments on the Cornwell sketches and describes planned changes to the painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, March 17, 1941
div1.opener:
CC for Dr. Hench
March 17th, 1941
Mrs. Estella Agramonte Rodriguez-Leon
15 Street, No. 311
Vedado, Havana
Dear Mrs. Rodriguez-Leon:
div1.p:
I have just received a letter from Dr. Philip Hench
of the Mayo Clinic in which he incloses a partial
copy of your recent letter to him concerning the
sketches made for the painting “The Conquest of Yellow
Fever”.

Your comments on the sketches, of which you must have
seen photographs, are of great value to both Mr. Cornwell
and myself. Due to information given us by Dr. Hench
we are changing the editorial idea of the painting.
Among the changes the background of the painting is to
be placed at Camp Columbia and while Dr. Finlay will be
in the picture he will be there as an observer at the
time at which Dr. Lazear is subjecting Dr. Carroll to
the bite of an infected mosquito. Dr. Agramonte will,
of course, take a prominent place in the picture.

I regret that Mr. Cornwell and I did not meet you while
in Havana. You would have saved us much time and
given us many suggestions of inestimable value. When
the new sketches are completed I shall send you photographs
with the hope that you will be willing to make suggestions.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, G. A. K. GAK:ef
